title: Domain 2.1: Compare and contrast Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP) ports, protocols, and their purposes.
content:
📦 Ports and Protocols

🔁 20/21 – FTP (File Transfer Protocol)

Transfers files between systems
Port 21 = control
Port 20 = data transfer

🧠 Exam Tip: Unsecured → use SFTP or FTPS for secure alternatives.

🔐 22 – SSH (Secure Shell)

Secure remote login and commands over an encrypted channel
Used by admins to access Linux servers

🧠 Exam Tip: SSH = Secure alternative to Telnet

💻 23 – Telnet

Remote login without encryption
Not secure, mostly obsolete now

🧠 Exam Tip: Only use Telnet in legacy scenarios.

📧 25 – SMTP (Simple Mail Transfer Protocol)

Sends outgoing email (client to mail server or between servers)

🧠 Exam Tip: Used to send email, not receive.

🌐 53 – DNS (Domain Name System)

Translates domain names (e.g., google.com) to IP addresses

🧠 Exam Tip: Port 53 uses BOTH TCP & UDP, depending on query size.

🛠️ 67/68 – DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol)

Assigns IP addresses automatically
Port 67 = server to client
Port 68 = client to server

🧠 Exam Tip: Client stuck with APIPA address (169.x.x.x)? DHCP likely failed.

🌍 80 – HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)

Basic, unencrypted web browsing

🧠 Exam Tip: Look for HTTPS (port 443) for secure web browsing.

📬 110 – POP3 (Post Office Protocol v3)

Used to download email and delete it from the server
One-way communication

🧠 Exam Tip: Contrast with IMAP (port 143) which syncs email.

🧾 137 / 139 – NetBIOS / NetBT (NetBIOS over TCP/IP)

Used for file and printer sharing in older Windows networks
Allows devices to discover and name each other

🧠 Exam Tip: Mostly legacy, but still seen in older file-sharing setups.

📩 143 – IMAP (Internet Message Access Protocol)

Retrieves incoming email
Keeps emails synced across multiple devices
Unlike POP3, doesn’t delete emails from server by default

🧠 Exam Tip: IMAP = Good for accessing email from multiple devices

📈 161 / 162 – SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol)

Used to monitor and manage network devices (routers, switches, printers)
161 = device listens
162 = trap/alert notifications

🧠 Exam Tip: Common with enterprise network monitoring tools

📚 389 – LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol)

Used for directory services (like Microsoft Active Directory)
Lets apps search for users, devices, groups, etc.

🧠 Exam Tip: Used in login systems and org-wide address books.

🔒 443 – HTTPS (HTTP Secure)

Secure version of HTTP
Uses SSL/TLS encryption for websites, login forms, payment portals

🧠 Exam Tip: Always pick HTTPS over HTTP for anything sensitive

📂 445 – SMB (Server Message Block) / CIFS

Used for file and printer sharing over Windows networks
Replaces NetBIOS in modern Windows systems
Runs directly over TCP/IP (no need for ports 137–139 anymore)

🧠 Exam Tip: If a Windows user can’t access a shared folder → check port 445.

🖥️ 3389 – Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP)

Allows you to remotely control a Windows computer as if you’re sitting in front of it
Uses port 3389 over TCP
Used by IT support teams and remote workers

🧠 Exam Tip: If a user can’t connect remotely, make sure port 3389 is open and Remote Desktop is enabled on the target machine.

🔁 TCP vs. UDP

⚡ UDP (User Datagram Protocol) – "Connectionless"

No handshakes, no guarantees. Faster, but no error checking or re-sending. Used when speed > reliability.

Examples:
DHCP – Assigns IP addresses fast
TFTP – Simple file transfers where errors don’t matter much

🧠 Exam Tip: UDP = Send it and forget it

🔗 TCP (Transmission Control Protocol) – "Connection-oriented"

Establishes a connection first (3-way handshake). Reliable, guaranteed delivery. Resends lost packets, ensures order.

Examples:
HTTPS – Secure web browsing
SSH – Secure remote shell sessions

🧠 Exam Tip: TCP = Slow but safe
